description.narrative: This pilot project aims to test some innovative income generation activities which is linked with the environment protection. Therefore, the project will increase the income of the 40 people (20 people in flower nursery, 10 men and 10 women) and 20 men (10 in compost making along with 5 men and 5 women in Bio-Briquette making) from poor and the most vulnerable IDPs by training them in the flower plant nursery, bio-briquette mold and compost making skills with linking to the market and environmental protection practices. They will be enabled to produce plant nurseries, bio-briquette mold, stove and organic fertilizer by their engagement in this projectand waste management practices. The project will provide them with specific tools and equipment and material which are utilized in producing their products. They are linked with the residential households and seed suppliers and customers for buying their products. Meanwhile, AREA and AYG will increase the awareness of 200 households and 400 (200 girls and 200 boys) school students through conducting awareness raising sessions and distribution of environmental protection messages. Other focus of this concept is to collect and manage the solid waste of 1,500 households in district five. The project will hirefour vulnerable IDPs/returnees by close coordination of the camp residence, they will collect the solid wastes from household level by using door-to-door collection methods or collection from community bins to prohibit the garbage mess up. The project will support the solid waste collection for six months by providing material inputs and salary subsidy, however to ensure further sustainability, the project team will establish a committee along with a saving box and register it within the ministry of justice. A certain amount of fee will be collected by agreement of this committee from households and this money will be used to pay the salary of waste collector, while the rest will be saved in the charity saving box and can be used as a small scales loan or will be invested in infrastructural projects

participating-org.narrative:
AYG is a non-political, non- governmental and non# profit, Afghan#s Youth organization to advocate and lobby with all the relevant governmental and non-governmental stakeholders to systematically address and mainstream the youths and environmental issues into their policies, programs, and to design and implement short-term, medium-term and long-term strategies and programs for promotion of environmental issues and for growth and expansion of talents, skills and potential of young women and men in economic, social, cultural and political areas of the country.
The mission of AYG is empowering the Afghan youths to find out the root cause of challenges towards youths# development and participation in economic, social, cultural and political decision making of the country through assessments, surveys and researches; as well as doing evidence based advocacy for promotion and capacity development of young women andmen for their empowerment with an overall goal of promoting the culture of green thinking; and advocacy for appropriate and sustainable use of natural resources in Afghanistan.
Now, AYG is active through its Head Quarter office in Kabul and two sub-offices in Bamyan and Daikundi provinces. AYG is working in collaboration of wide national and international networks, e.g. AYG is an active member of Afghan Women#s Network (AWN), Civil Society- Environment Natural Resources Monitoring Network (CS-ENRMN), local communities, female and male youths in Kabul as well as in the different provinces of Afghanistan.
At the international level, AYG is member of Global Young Greens (GYG). Since AYG is member of Global Young Greens (GYG), it will also follow the Global Greens charter in implementation of its programs/activities.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
